When events are investigated and root causes are identified, solutions are assigned to individuals and the responsible supervisors are required to verify that the solutions are complete and they are required to validate that the solution addresses the root cause (V&V).  

For this RMP report, where minor losses or near losses were identified in covered facilities, the latest such incident investigation was listed in section 7.11 (Prevention Program, Incident Investigation).  


GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS
The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the Chevron Salt Lake Refinery.  Because processes at the refinery that are regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the OSHA PSM standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and briefly describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.

Employee Participation
The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery understands that engaging the entire work force is a key to the success of an effective prevention program and encourages all employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention.  To further empower workers and advocate a safe working environment, every employee and contractor is given a A Stop Work Authority Card that allows each of them to stop any unsafe act without reprisal. This authority not only allows them to use stop work, but is an expectation of employment to stop all potentially unsafe tasks.  

Chevron Salt Lake Refinery has adopted ten Tenets of Operation.  These tenets include operating within design limits, following procedures, ensuring safety devices are functioning, etc.  Copies of these tenets are posted around the refinery and management reinforces their importance and encourages workers to use their stop work authority if these tenet

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES
The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances and our goal is to be Injury and Incident Free (IIF).  If a release does occur, refinery personnel are trained to respond to all types of events, including the control and containment of releases and the appropriate emergency response.


DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery, located in North Salt Lake, Utah, operates a variety of processes to produce petroleum products (e.g., refinery fuel gas, propane, butane, gasoline, jet fuel, diesel, petroleum coke, sulfur) from raw crude oil.  

The refinery has several regulated flammables on site.  Included in this are:

- Hydrogen
- Methane
- Ethane
- Ethylene
- Propane
- Propylene
- Butane
- Butene
- Isobutane
- Isobutene
- 2-butene-cis
- 2-butene-trans
- 2-Methylpropene
- 1,3 Butadiene
- Pentane
- Isopentane
- 2,2-Dimethylpropane

The only regulated toxic substance that the refinery has above threshold quantities is hydrogen fluoride.  


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been 0 incidents subject to RMP 5-Year Accident History reporting in the past five years.    

The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery has an excellent record of accident prevention. The refinery has an integrated Loss Prevention System (LPS) where losses and near losses are reported and investigated.  By addressing all minor losses, the refinery reduces the probability of major incidents.  

The LPS process involves the refinery work force at all levels.  It places ownership of the process on line mana

s are not followed.  

Additionally, examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. Employees have access to all information generated from the refinery accident prevention program.  Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan that is maintained at the refinery and addresses each accident prevention program element.  

Process Safety Information
The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters including specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis and configuration information.  Specific departments within the refinery are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information. 

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards, emergency response and exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals.  For specific process areas, the refinery has documented safety-related limits for each unit's process parameters, including Safe Upper and Lower Limit and Consequence of Deviation tables.   Operating parameters are also documented in operating procedures, in the electronic control systems, and in equipment Safety Information Sheets (SIS).  The process parameters include temperature, level, composition and pressure.  The refinery ensures that the processes are maintained within these limits using process controls, instrumentation monitoring, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutd

own systems).  Employees understand the consequences of operating outside of specified limits and the steps needed to avoid operating outside them.  

The refinery also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provide a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis
The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.

The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery primarily uses the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations.  HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques.  The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience, as well as expertise in systems control technology and engineering.  This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.  

PHA team findings are reviewed and findings are assigned to individuals and work groups for resolution.  Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team.  This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the h

ighest risk receive priority attention.  Refinery management is also involved in reviewing PHA corrective actions and providing the resources to assure their timely completion.  All approved mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and this documentation is retained.

Chevron Salt Lake Refinery periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis.  These reviews include not only the original study data, but they include process changes in the last five years that have been made through the MOC process and they include a review of incidents both in the unit and in other similar units throughout industry.  Periodic reviews are conducted at least every five years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.  

Operating Procedures
The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process.  Operating procedures cover critical and infrequently performed tasks and provides a basis for consistent training of new operators.  The management of change (MOC) process includes steps to update and modify procedures to reflect changes made in the plants.    

Training
To complement the written procedures for process operations, the Chevron Salt Lake Refinery has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  All new employees receive basic training in refinery operations, safety and emergency response.  New operators attend five weeks of a Formal Operator Training Program (FOTP) where details of plant operation are taught.  After successfully completing this classroom and field training,

and passing a number or written exams, a new operator is paired with an experienced operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the plant operation, plant specific operating procedures, and they again review all changes made and any incidents that have occurred in the specific units.  All of this training is documented for each operator, including testing and coaching to verify that the operator understood the training.

Contractors
The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, ensuring the competency of the contractors and their employees is critical to the safe operations of the facility.  The refinery has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform refinery personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.  

Salt Lake Refinery has a comprehensive Contractor Health, Safety & Environment Management (CHESM) process to assess and pre-qualify contractors before they can work in the refinery.  To bid on contracts at the facility, the contractor must demonstrate the effectiveness of their training and safety programs.  Once the contractor is on site, the contractors must maintain exceptional safety records and they must participate in the refinery's safety programs and initiatives.  Prior to their beginning work at the refinery each contractor is  provided training through

the site specific training program in (1) information about safety and health hazards, (2) emergency response plan requirements, and (3) training on safe work practices.  Specific training on the refinery's Loss Prevention System and Incident and Injury Free Operations programs are also included in each contractor's orientation.  

As part of the CHESM Process, refinery personnel monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations. To ensure a continued safe work environment, the Chevron Salt Lake Refinery systematically evaluates contractor safety programs and performance.  

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)
The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery conducts a PSSR for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that all variables such as procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for a safe startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  The PSSR review team, consisting of both employees and contractors, uses checklists to verify various aspects of readiness.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integrity
The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe and reliable operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) employee training and competency, (2) written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality ass

urance measures.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.

Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe manner.  

Preventative maintenance is performed on equipment to ensure safe and reliable operations.  Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable operating limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels).  If a deficiency is identified or if equipment is found to be approaching end of life, the risk is assessed and plans are put in place to mitigate the risk and/or correct the deficiency and remove the equipment from service before the equipment becomes a hazard.  

Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance.  The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.  These processes include the refinery's Positive Material Identification (PMI) process, vendor selection process and design standards.  These processes help ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made. 

Safe Work Practices
The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include (1) control of the entry, presence and exit of support personnel from the process unit, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e

., hot work), and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These and other procedures, along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

Management of Change
The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to mitigate any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.  Through the MOC process, any affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, equipment information, and operating procedures are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, all affected operating and maintenance personnel are provided training on the change in a timely manner.

Incident Investigation
The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire or explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental release, or personal injury.  Incident investigations follow written guidelines to determine the root causes and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings and develops recommended solutions or corrective actions to prevent a recurrence. All solutions are entered into a database for tracking completion and for management verification and validation.  Under the refinery's Loss Prevention System (LPS), each work group reviews pertinent incidents during their monthly LPS team meetings.  Additionally, all employees have access to the investigation

database where they can review incidents, findings and resolutions to the recommended solutions. Refinery management has the responsibility to verify and validate that all solutions are completed in a timely manner.  

Compliance Audits
To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Chevron routinely conducts compliance audits to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the program are being implemented and if improvements can be made.  These compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years or more frequently as changes in operations occur.  The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to refinery management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete.  Quarterly updates are required by Chevron Management.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.  


CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
Chevron Salt Lake Refinery uses administrative controls and work processes to identify hazards that must be managed and mitigated to ensure continued safe operation. The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all Program 3 EPA RMP-covered process at the Chevron Salt Lake Refinery. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures or human errors.

Additionally, the Chevron Salt Lake Refinery has installed engineering controls as  safety features to help (1) contain or control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of a release (mitigate).  The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

Release Containment/Control
1. Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases

2. Emergency Block Valves to isolate the process (manual or automated)

3. Automated shutdown systems for specifi

c process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature)

4. Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases

5. Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, backup power, backup pumps)

6. Trained emergency response personnel

7. Atmospheric relief devices


Release Mitigation
1.  Fire extinguishing system

2.  Water spray systems to mitigate a hydrogen fluoride release or to provide fire water to specific pieces of equipment.  

3.  Gas scrubber systems


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery maintains a written Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including clouds of hazardous vapors or chemical spills, responding to a fire or explosion, or other emergencies.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition, the Chevron Salt Lake Refinery has procedures that address the maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in the procedures necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The emergency response program is updated when necessary. 

The overall emergency response program for the Chevron Salt Lake Refinery is coordinated with the South Davis Metro Fire Agency and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which are attended by local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery has around-the-clock com

munications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Chevron Salt Lake Refinery conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Chevron Salt Lake Refinery is committed to continual safety improvement and incident free operation.  All safety programs are managed and monitored through the Operational Excellence Management System. Additionally, there are a number of processes in place that are specifically designed to improve safety and reliability.  These include the resolution processes for resolving all findings from process hazards analysis, incident investigations, and compliance audits mentioned above.   The refinery has instituted a Loss Prevention System that includes safety observations, loss reporting, and near loss reporting.  These are all part of the refinery's continual emphasis on Incident and Injury Free operations.  Each health and safety process requires periodic self-assessment to identify areas for continual improvements.  These processes and programs, along with the incorporation of the other PSM elements assure an environment of continual safety improvement and release prevention.
